Introduction: 
 Credit cards are not a simple financial product and should not be used complacently. In this lesson we will learn about how best to use them. 
 
 Understand the basics: 
 A credit card is a way of borrowing money that lets you buy items now up to a pre determined credit limit and then pay later for them. 
 Payments for these items can be made in one go or in installments.
 Each time you spend, the amount will be added to the card's balance. This balance is the total amount you owe to the bank.

Credit cards are one of the most popular consumer financial products in the UK, however inappropriate use can generate unmanageable debts. In this lesson we will learn how best to use them.
A credit card is a way of borrowing money that lets you buy items now, up to a pre determined credit limit and then pay later for them.
•Payments for these items can be made in one go or in instalments. \n•Each time you spend, the amount will be added to the card\'s balance. \n•The balance is the total amount you owe to the bank.

Balances should be paid off at the end of each month.
Alternatively you can repay it in the future with added interest.
The amount of interest will vary depending on:
•How long it takes you to pay off your balance
•The APR (Annual Percentage Rate) associated with your credit card.
